# word frequencies


## Words are not distributed evenly

It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife. 
However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families, that he is considered the rightful property of some one or other of their daughters. 

“My dear Mr. Bennet,” said his lady to him one day, “have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last?” 
Mr. Bennet replied that he had not. 

“But it is,” returned she; “for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she told me all about it.” 
Mr. Bennet made no answer. 

“Do you not want to know who has taken it?” cried his wife impatiently. 
“You want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it.” 
This was invitation enough.

## Function words & inflected languages

**Jak** powszechnie wiadomo, Wszechświat -- podobnie **jak** życie -- 
toczy **się** kołem. Kołem, **na** **którego** obręczy zaznaczono osiem 
magicznych punktów, dających pełny obrót, **czyli** cykl roczny. Punktami 
**tymi**, leżącymi **na** obręczy koła **w** parach dokładnie 
**naprzeciw** siebie, **są**: Imbaelk -- **czyli** Kiełkowanie, Lammas -- 
**czyli** Dojrzewanie, Belleteyn -- Rozkwit **oraz** Saovine -- Zamieranie. 
**Są** **także** **na** kole zaznaczone dwa Solstycja, **czyli** 
Przesilenia -- zimowe, zwane Midinvaerne **oraz** Midaete, letnie. **Są** 
**także** dwa Ekwinokcja, **czyli** Równonoce -- Birke, wiosenna **i** 
Velen, jesienna. Daty **te** dzielą okrąg **na** osiem części -- **i** 
**tak** **też** **w** kalendarzu elfów dzieli **się** rok.

## 3rd Zipf's Law

The more frequent a word, the more meanings it has



## An example: Zipf's law

```{r laws1, echo = FALSE, message = FALSE}
load("R_datasets/Rozm_freqs.Rdata")
p = plot_ly(y = Rozm[1:300,1], type = "scatter", mode = "markers", text = rownames(Rozm)[1:300])
p
```



## Zipf's law on a log-log scale

```{r laws2, echo = FALSE, message = FALSE}
p = plot_ly(y = Rozm[,1], type = "scatter", mode = "markers", text = rownames(Rozm)) %>%
        layout(xaxis = list(type = "log"), yaxis = list(type = "log"))
p
```


## The least effort principle

```{r laws3, echo = FALSE, message = FALSE}
p = plot_ly(y = Rozm[,2], type = "scatter", mode = "markers", text = rownames(Rozm)) %>%
        layout(xaxis = list(type = "log"))
p
```


## The least effort: another example


```{r laws6, echo = FALSE, message = FALSE}
txt = readLines("R_datasets/Libahunt.txt")
Libahunt = sort(table(tolower(unlist(strsplit(txt, "\\W+")))), decreasing = TRUE)
p = plot_ly(y = nchar(names(Libahunt)), type = "scatter", mode = "markers", text = rownames(Libahunt)) %>%
        layout(xaxis = list(type = "log"))
p
```







## Menzerath-Altman law

- The increase of the size of a linguistic construct results in a decrease of the size of its constituents, and vice versa.
- E.g., the longer a sentence, the shorter the clauses.
- E.g., the longer a word (in syllables or morphemes), the shorter the syllables or morphemes in sounds.




## Heap's Law

```{r laws4, echo = FALSE, message = FALSE}
# heaps
library(stylo)
data(novels)
txt = tolower(unlist(strsplit(novels[[1]], "\\W+")))
results = NULL
for(i in 2:length(txt)) { 
    seen = txt[i] %in% txt[1:(i-1)]
    results = c(results, seen)
}
plot(cumsum(!results), ylab = "unseen words", xlab = "running words", col = "blue")
```
